Let us head off to and play with some iterated functions in the Complex Plane. This will lead us into an intuitive understanding of Julia and Mandelbrot Fractals. Now we are ready(?) to understand this video on Julia fractals! {{< video https://youtu.be/2AZYZ-L8m9Q >}} {{< video https://youtu.be/8ma6cV6fw24 >}} ## Designing with Julia/Mandelbrot fractals Let us play with this interactive Mandelbrot-Julia combination diagram! 1. We now that the Mandelbrot fractal uses the Iterated Function $z \leftarrow ~ z^2 + C$, where $C$ is a starting complex constant. 1. The Mandelbrot (at left) is plotted in a coordinate space for $C$. 1. The Julia(s) (at right) are plotted in a coordinate space for $z$. 1. Depending upon the starting value of $C$ in the Mandelbrot we get a different choice of Julia fractal in the right side diagram. 1. In this "single-colour" Mandelbrot, we see that for those values of $C$ where the corresponding Julia is ***connected***, the $C$ point is coloured black in the Mandelbrot. Else it is coloured white and appears to be "outside". 1. Place your cursor inside the Julia diagram. A connected Julia always shows an iterative trace that lies within itself. A dis-connected Julia has points going off to infinity... 1. Varying $C$ we see a systematic variation of the attainable Julia fractals. ### Jewellery Shopping with Mandelbrot Ever gone shopping for jewellery? How is the place organized? That is a good metaphor for how Mandelbrot Set is generated!! Here is an image to complete the Jewellery Store metaphor: ![Mandelbrot and Julia Mapping](../../../../../materials/images/Mandelbrot and Julia Mapping.png){#fig-mandelbrot-julia-mapping} ## Fractals with Code ::: {.panel-tabset .nav-pills style="background: whitesmoke;"} ### Using p5.js And here is the Julia set: See also this sketch for a static Julia, set by a user choice of $C$. ::: {.content-hidden when-format="html"} ### Using R ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true"} library(blogdown) library(tidyverse) library(ggformula) ### library(LindenmayeR) library(LearnGeom) library(TurtleGraphics) ### library(mosaicCalc) # Analytic Calculus library(ambient) # Noise generation in R library(plot3D) # 3D plots for explanation library(caracas) library(downloadthis) library(knitr) library(kableExtra) ## Markdown boiler plate stuff!! A sample screen to explore the Mandelbrot fractal is here: ::: ## {{< iconify mingcute thought-line >}} Wait, But Why? - Fractal shapes are all around us in nature - These mathematically created fractal shapes can have uses that are limited only by your imagination: want to design footwear that does not slip? - Different parts of the Mandelbrot fractal allow us to contemplate a variety of fractal shapes - And if we choose [a different IFS function](https://larryriddle.agnesscott.org/ifs/ifs.htm) (rather than $z \rightarrow z^2 + C$), we can think of entire families of shapes! ## {{< iconify ooui references-ltr >}} References 1.
